head.title: A 'Silent' Generation Speaks Up, and Not So Softly

hedline.hl1: A 'Silent' Generation Speaks Up, and Not So Softly

abstract.p: Norm Crandus, letter, responds to Fred Brock's May 7 article on 'silent' generation, those Americans, now in the mid-50's to early 70's, who are too young to have fought in World War II but too old to be considered baby boomers; drawing (M)

block.p: In ''The Silent Generation Seeks Its Due (May 7)'' Fred Brock looked at Americans who are too young to have fought in World War II but too old to be considered baby boomers. Members of that age group, in their mid-50's to early 70's, often feel overlooked by employers, marketers and the popular culture.
I have often wondered where I was in the world. After reading your article last Sunday I now know where I am, who I am, and what my name is. Thank you.
But . . . I had a war but little blood. I served in the Army during the Korean conflict and heard the Russian artillery across the border during our maneuvers.
